text: What are the possible GitHub account types? (Select three.)

options.text: Personal accounts
Organization accounts
Enterprise accounts
Shared accounts
Company accounts

text: Which of these GitHub features serves the purpose of an adaptable spreadsheet, task board and a roadmap that integrates with issues and pull requests on GitHub to plan and track your work effectively?

options.text: GitHub Project
GitHub Copilot
GitHub Repository
GitHub Organization

text: How does the synchronization between GitHub projects, issues and pull requests work?

options.text: Updates to the issues and pull requests will be automatically reflected in GitHub Projects. This integration works both ways, so that when you change information about a pull request or issue in your project, the pull request or issue reflects that information.
Updates to the issues and pull requests will not be automatically reflected in GitHub Projects, it has to be triggered manually by the user.
Information synchronization only works in one direction - from project to issues and pull requests. Updates to issues and pull requests won't be automatically mirrored in GitHub Project items.
Information synchronization only works in one direction - from issues and pull requests to projects. Updates to Project items won't be automatically mirrored in issues and pull requests.

text: Which of these is true regarding custom fields for items in GitHub Projects?

options.text: Custom fields enable the addition of metadata beyond the built-in options, such as target dates and iteration fields.
Custom fields are limited to textual information and cannot include numeric or date-related metadata.
Custom fields are exclusively for aesthetic modifications and do not add any meaningful metadata.
Custom fields are limited to predefined options and cannot include user-defined metadata.

text: What are the different available options for adding issues and pull requests to a GitHub Project board?

options.text: Individually, automatically, or in bulk.
Only manually, one at a time.
Only individually or in bulk
Only automatically using project workflows

text: Which of these layouts are available in GitHub Projects? (Choose three.)

options.text: Table layout
Board layout
Roadmap layout
Scrum layout
Agile layout
Project layout

text: Which GitHub Project layout would best serve as a Kanban board?

options.text: Board layout
Table layout
Roadmap layout
Agile layout

text: Which of these workflows are built-in automations in GitHub Projects? (Choose two.)

options.text: When issues or pull requests in your project are closed, their status is set to Done
When pull requests in your project are merged, their status is set to Done.
When issues or pull requests are opened in your project, their status is set to Done.
When a new contributor is added to a repository, the unassigned issues are assigned to him.
When a GitHub Action is triggered, create a new item in your GitHub Project.

options.text: Project workflows

text: What is the difference between GitHub projects and GitHub projects classic?

options.text: GitHub Projects is a the new GitHub experience which offers a lot of new features and improvements over the older GitHub Projects classic.
GitHub Projects classic is a the new GitHub experience which offers a lot of new features and improvements over the older GitHub Projects.
GitHub Projects classic is simpler way to manage your GitHub Projects and is recommended for beginners.
GitHub Projects classic is the enhanced versions which in addition to GitHub Projects offers some pre-cooked templates such as roadmaps and sprints.

text: What are the use cases for labels?

options.text: Categorizing issues and pull requests
Categorizing files in the repository
Assigning them to releases so that they are included in the release notes
Assigning labels to repository contributors to indicate their role and permissions in the project

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-to-track-work/managing-labels

You can't assign labels to releases. You can't assign labels to contributors

text: Why would a repository owner want to use milestones? (Choose two.)

options.text: To associate issues and pull requests with specific project phases
To have an overview of how much work is left to complete a project phase
To bring automation to the repository
To communicate that the repository is in a stable state
To track the repository dependencies
To list the repository contributors

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-to-track-work/about-milestones

That's what GitHub Actions is for. That's what Dependency graph and Dependabot are for

text: How can you assign a person to an issue or pull request?

By adding a label with their GitHub username to that issue or pull request

text: If you face yourself often writing the same set of comments on issues or pull requests, what GitHub feature would you use to save time?

Saved replies are comments that you can reuse in issues and pull requests.

Saved replies are only available to repository owners which can setup automated replies to issues and pull requests.

text: GitHub Action workflows are triggered by events. Which of these are valid events that GitHub Actions support? (Choose two.)

options.text: A commit is pushed to a branch
A pull request is opened
A change is made to the repository settings
A new vulnerability has been detected in a dependency
A new member has been added to the repository

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/events-that-trigger-workflows#about-events-that-trigger-workflows

This is not a valid event that could trigger a workflow. It's a feature of Dependabot.

text: Is GitHub Copilot free to use?

options.text: No
Yes
Yes, if you are a student, teacher, or maintainer of a popular open source project
Yes, but only for individuals working on public repositories

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/overview-of-github-copilot/about-github-copilot-individual#understanding-the-differences-between-copilot-individual-and-copilot-business

There is a free trial. However GitHub Copilot is a paid feature even for Individuals.

text: What are the differences between GitHub Copilot Individual and GitHub Copilot Business?

options.text: GitHub Copilot Individual can only be used by personal accounts and GitHub Copilot Business is used by organizations and enterprises
GitHub Copilot Individual uses an AI model trained on public source code and GitHub Copilot Business uses an AI model trained on private source code
GitHub Copilot Individual is free and GitHub Copilot Business is a paid feature
GitHub Copilot Individual can only be used when working on public repositories and GitHub Copilot Business can be used when working on public and private repositories within an organization

text: How can you start using GitHub Copilot after activating the GitHub Copilot subscription?

options.text: Setup GitHub Copilot in one of the supported IDE's such as Visual Studio Code or JetBrains and start coding
GitHub Copilot will automatically start giving suggestions on pull requests and issues in your repository
You need to setup a GitHub Action that will setup GitHub Copilot on your repository
You need to edit the repository settings and enable GitHub Copilot for the repository

text: What is a GitHub Codespace?

options.text: It's a preconfigured development environment specifically setup for a repository. It allows you immediately start writing code for a project without having to setup a local development environment.
A GitHub Codespace is an interactive holographic coding environment that required special hardware to use.
GitHub Codespace is an AI-powered coding tool that auto-generates near flawless code
GitHub Codespace is an annual GitHub hosted event where developers can meet and discuss coding topics.

text: What GitHub feature allows the creation of preconfigured development environments where all necessary tools and dependencies to contribute to a repository are installed?

options.text: GitHub Codespaces
GitHub Docker

github.dev editor

text: What are the different possible lifecycle phases for a GitHub Codespace?

options.text: Create, Rebuild, Stop, Delete
Create, Delete
Create, Stop, Delete
Create, Rebuild, Delete

text: If you stop your GitHub Codespace environment can you come back to the changes later if you haven't committed them?

options.text: Yes, that's the default behavior when stopping and then starting a GitHub Codespace
No, these changes will be lost. You need to commit them before stopping the Codespace.

text: Which of these statements regarding GitHub Codespaces lifecycle are true? (Choose three.)

options.text: A Codespace's lifecycle begins when you create a Codespace and ends when you delete it.
You can stop and restart a Codespace without losing the changes that you make to your project.
You can disconnect and reconnect to an active Codespace without affecting its running processes.
You can stop and restart a Codespace without affecting its running processes.
If you create another Codespace on a branch which already had a Codespace running on it, the original Codespace will be deleted
If you close the browser tab in which your Codespace was running, the Codespace will automatically be stopped

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/codespaces/getting-started/understanding-the-codespace-lifecycle

Closing the browser tab does not stop the Codespace and the processes continue running. If you only closed the tab, the Codespace will stop after reaching the inactivity timeout period

text: Your project requires appropriate hardware to run. Can you customize the amount of CPU cores that will be allocated to your GitHub Codespace environment?

options.text: Yes, you can choose an alternative machine type either when you create a codespace or at any time after you've created a codespace.
No, GitHub Codespaces are hosted on Microsoft Azure and we have no control on what hardware they are running

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/codespaces/customizing-your-codespace/changing-the-machine-type-for-your-codespace

GitHub Codespaces are indeed hosted on Microsoft Azure, but you can configure the machine type to use

text: How can you customize the environment that is run in GitHub Codespaces?

options.text: By creating a .devcontainer/devcontainer.json configuration file
By creating a custom Dockerfile in the root of your repository
By creating a .github/codespaces.yml configuration file
By creating custom machine images with the repository installed

options.text: It's a link that points to a specific GitHub.com Page that allows you to create a new GitHub Codespace and select specific configuration
It's a link between the GitHub Codespace and the repository which keeps the Codespace in sync with the changes in the repository
It's a link to the most recent GitHub Codespace that was created for the repository
It's a link to the most recent GitHub Codespace that you have used in any repository

text: Who are repository collaborators?

options.text: Collaborators are people who have been granted write access to a repository.

text: What is the role of an organization moderator?

Moderators are organization members who can view security alerts and manage settings for code security across your organization, as well as read permissions for all repositories in the organization.

That's organization owners. That's billing managers. That's security managers

Security managers are organization members who, in addition to their permissions as members, are allowed to block and unblock non-member contributors, set interaction limits, and hide comments in public repositories owned by the organization.
Security managers are organization members who have complete access to the organization.
Security managers are organization members who can manage the billing settings for your organization, such as payment information.

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/organizations/managing-peoples-access-to-your-organization-with-roles/roles-in-an-organization

That's moderators. That's organization owners. That's billing managers

options.text: A well-crafted collection of markdown documents like README.md, CONTRIBUTING.md and others.

Covering the repository software with tests

text: Which of these statements best describes a version control system?

options.text: It's a system that tracks the history of changes made to a collection of files.
It's a system that leverages the git command line tool.
It's a system that allows you to create a local copy of a project's source code.
It's a system that allows tracking of what people install on their computers.

text: What is the meaning of the word distributed in distributed version control system?

options.text: It means that developers can have a full copy of the repository and its history on their local machine.
It means that tasks among the team members using the system are easily distributed.
The term refers to the peer-to-peer sharing of code files among users.
It means that the codebase is distributed across multiple servers for load balancing.

text: Which of these best describes git?

options.text: Git is a distributed version control system.
Git is a centralized version control system.
Git is the product of GitHub that allows for version control.
Git is a file sharing system.

text: Which of these statements best describes what GitHub is?

options.text: GitHub is a platform that uses Git as its core technology and adds features that make collaboration and code management easier.
GitHub is a distributed version control system with features that make collaboration on projects easy.
GitHub is a file sharing platform with features that make collaboration on projects easy using centralized version control.
GitHub is a modern CI/CD platform with features that help drive rapid product development.

text: What is the relation between Git and GitHub?

options.text: Git is a distributed version control system and GitHub is a platform that uses Git as its core technology.
GitHub is a distributed version control system and Git is a platform that uses GitHub as its core technology.
Git is a file sharing system and GitHub is a platform that uses Git as its core technology.
GitHub is a file sharing system and Git is a platform that uses GitHub as its core technology.

options.text: It's a place where you can store your code, your files, and each file's revision history.
It's a place where you can store your Docker images or NPM packages.
It's a visual code editor that allows you to edit your source code in the browser.
A repository in GitHub is a chat room where developers can discuss code-related issues.

text: What is a git commit?

options.text: A commit is a snapshot of a repository at a specific point in time.
A commit refers to a new or updated file in a repository.
A commit refers to the code changes made to a repository in a pull request.

options.text: branch
commit
remote
working tree

text: What is the GitHub Flow?

options.text: It refers to a branch-based workflow where developers create a branch for each new change they're working on, and then open pull requests to get their code reviewed, tested, and merged into the main branch.
It's a practice where every time a commit is pushed to the main branch, a new release is automatically created and deployed.
It's a practice where every time a commit is pushed to the main branch, a set of CI/CD pipelines are triggered to run tests and validate the code changes.
It refers to a one branch workflow where developers work on their features on the master branch, and then get their feature code reviewed, tested, and committed.

That pull request will be automatically merged on the 11th of that month.

text: In GitHub a proposal to merge a set of changes from one branch into another branch is called a:

options.text: Pull Request
Gist
Issue
Commit
A merge branch

text: You want to merge changes from branch feature-a into main and you are creating a pull request. Which branch should be the base branch and which branch should be the compare branch?

options.text: main is the base branch and feature-a is the compare branch.
feature-a is the base branch and main is the compare branch.

text: What are draft pull requests?

options.text: Draft pull requests are pull requests that are not ready to be reviewed yet.
Draft pull requests are pull requests that have already been reviewed but not merged.
Draft pull requests are pull requests that have already been reviewed but not approved.
Draft pull requests are templates for creating new pull requests.

text: What are the possible statuses for a pull request review? (Choose three.)

options.text: Comment
Approve
Request Changes
Close
Deny
Applaud

text: Which of these statements about the differences of issues and discussions is true?

options.text: GitHub Discussions are for conversations that need to be transparent and accessible but do not need to be tracked on a project board and are not related to code, unlike GitHub Issues.
GitHub Issues are for conversations that need to be transparent and accessible but do not need to be tracked on a project board and are not related to code, unlike GitHub Discussions.

text: Which of the GitHub features best serves as a simple way to share small code snippets with others?

options.text: Gists
Wikis
Issues
Projects

text: What are GitHub Wikis?

options.text: Wikis is repository feature for hosting documentation.
Wikis is the official GitHub documentation.
Wikis is a feature for hosting code snippets.
Wikis is a place where you hold the project's README.md file.

text: What are the two available options when you no longer need to use a Project?

options.text: Delete and archive
Close and delete
Archive and close
Deactivate and archive

text: Can you change a gist from public to secret after creating it?

options.text: Yes
No

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/writing-on-github/editing-and-sharing-content-with-gists/creating-gists

After creating a gist, you cannot convert it from public to secret.

text: What happens when you choose to close a Project?

options.text: The project is permanently removed from the platform
The content is retained and you have the ability to reopen it later.
Associated values and insights data are deleted
The Project is moved to a separate folder

text: If there are multiple Readme.md files in a GitHub repository, what is the priority order to show them?

options.text: Root directory, .docs directory, .github directory
.docs directory, Root directory, .github directory
.github directory, Root directory, .docs directory
.docs directory, .github directory, Root directory

text: Which of the following Git commands allow you to create a new branch and start working on it in one line? (Select two.)

options.text: git checkout -b `<new_branch_name
git branch -c `<new_branch_name
git switch -c `<new_branch_name
git merge -m `<new_branch_name
git switch -m `<new_branch_name
git checkout -m `<new_branch_name

text: If a GitHub Discussion is converted into an Issue and the issue is closed or referred to using its corresponding # number, will the discussion be modified?

options.text: No
Yes

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/creating-an-issue#creating-an-issue-from-discussion

When you "convert" a discussion into an Issue it essentially creates a new issue that is soft linked to the discussion and pre-fills the issue information. There isn't a bigger connection between them.

text: Which information can be found in the Pulse section in the Insights tab of a repository? (Choose four)

options.text: Pull requests open/merged ratio
Summary of repository activity
Amount of code line additions and deletions
List of issue discussions
List of unresolved conversations
Amount of forks of the repo

text: What are the different levels of GitHub organizational hierarchy? (Choose three.)

options.text: Team level
Organization level
Personal level
Pro level
Enterprise level

explanation:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/github-introduction-administration/2-what-is-github-administration

GitHub Personal is a type of account and not an organizational hierarchy on GitHub.. GitHub Pro is a type of account and not an organizational hierarchy on GitHub.

text: Who can setup billing or assign billing managers for an organization? (Select three.)

options.text: Owner of the repository
Team maintainer at the team level
Admin in at the team level
Billing managers at the organization level
Owner at the organization level
Owner at the enterprise level

explanation: Official GitHub documentation: https://docs.github.com/en/organizations/managing-peoples-access-to-your-organization-with-roles/adding-a-billing-manager-to-your-organization, Microsoft Learn study guide: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/github-introduction-administration/2-what-is-github-administration

text: What is one of the main benefits for using a Personal Access Token (PAT) instead of a standard username and password for GitHub authentication?

options.text: PATs can be managed by the organization and enterprise.

PAT is an extra layer of security used when logging into websites or apps. With PAT, users have to sign in with their username and password and provide another form of authentication that only they have access to.

PAT can be used for authentication to GitHub when using the GitHub API or the command line. Users generate a token via the GitHub's settings option, and tie the token permissions to a repository or organization.
PAT lets you authenticate GitHub Enterprise Server against your existing accounts and centrally manage repository access.

explanation:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/github-introduction-administration/3-how-github-authentication-works

PAT's as the name suggests, are personal. Organizations and Enterprises can manage other forms of authentication, such as LDAP, SAML, and SSH keys.. This is a description of multi-factor or two-factor authentication.. This is a description of LDAP's benefits for GitHub, not PAT.

text: What are the different forms of two-factor or multi-factor authentication supported by GitHub? (Choose five.)

options.text: Passkey
Text message
Phone call
Email
Security key
GitHub mobile

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/securing-your-account-with-two-factor-authentication-2fa/accessing-github-using-two-factor-authentication

While text messages are supported in some countries, phone calls are not

options.text: Free
Team
Enterprise
Pro
Personal
Business

options.text: Free
Team
Enterprise
Pro
Personal
Business

text: What syntax is used in GitHub Markdown to create a task list?

# TODO: and # DONE:

`<task

text: Which Markdown element is not correctly paired with its syntax?

options.text: Heading - # Heading
Bold text - **bold**

Hyperlink - [title](https://)

text: What feature is unique to GitHub Desktop compared to github.com?

options.text: Clone repositories to local machine
Create new repositories
View repository insights
Visualize branch histories in a graphical interface

explanation: GitHub Desktop provides a graphical interface for visualizing branch histories, which is unique compared to the website. - https://docs.github.com/en/desktop/making-changes-in-a-branch/viewing-the-branch-history-in-github-desktop. - https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-data-for-your-repository/using-the-activity-view-to-see-changes-to-a-repository

text: Which of the following actions cannot be performed directly from GitHub Desktop?

options.text: Stashing changes
Managing GitHub Actions
Switching between branches
Committing changes

explanation: Managing GitHub Actions is not a feature available in GitHub Desktop and must be done via github.com or CI/CD integration. - https://docs.github.com/en/actions/quickstart#prerequisites

text: What are some actions you can do in regards to Project Templates in your organization? (Choose three.)

options.text: With write permission, set an existing project as a template
Configure recommended templates to your organization's members
Create a new template to be used as a base for new projects
With admin or write permissions, copy an existing project as a template
Publish your templates in GitHub Marketplace for anyone to use

explanation:
https://docs.github.com/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-projects/managing-your-project/managing-project-templates-in-your-organization

You need admin permissions to set an existing project as a template

text: Which of the following is true about GitHub wikis?

options.text: Wikis in private repositories are accessible to anyone with a GitHub account.
You can only edit wikis directly on GitHub; local editing is not supported.
Wikis in public repositories are accessible to anyone, while those in private repositories are only accessible to repository collaborators.
Markdown cannot be used to add rendered math expressions, diagrams, maps, and 3D models to a wiki.

options.text: Read
Triage
Delete
Admin

Maintain

options.text: Push commits
Manage issues and pull requests
Delete the repository
Change repository settings
Create new repositories

text: Which of these is a capability of a Security Manager with respect to GitHub Actions in an organization?

options.text: They can configure which actions are allowed or blocked across the organization.
They can delete all workflow runs from private repositories that are over 90 days old.
They can turn off code reviews for repositories in the organization.
They can remove the Require status checks to pass before merging branch protection rule.

text: Which feature provides pre-built charts or visualizations for repository activity and health?

options.text: Insights tab
GitHub Actions
GitHub Projects
GitHub Discussions

options.text: Organization-wide policy management, including restricting model suggestions based on public code
Exemption from all paid usage fees
24/7 phone support from GitHub Copilot team
Local hosting of the AI model behind GitHub Copilot

text: What is the main difference between an organization member and an outside collaborator for a repository owned by that organization?

options.text: Outside collaborators have repository-level access but are not part of the organization; members belong to the organization and may have broader access and roles.
Outside collaborators can manage billing settings, while members cannot.
Members can never contribute to private repositories, while outside collaborators can.
Outside collaborators automatically become team maintainers in the organization.

explanation: **More info**: [Adding outside collaborators to repositories in your organization](https://docs.github.com/en/organizations/managing-access-to-your-organizations-repositories/adding-outside-collaborators-to-repositories-in-your-organization)

text: Which of the following actions can you perform on a GitHub Discussion? (Choose three.)

options.text: Pin a discussion
Transfer it to another repository discussion (if you have admin permissions)
Convert the discussion to a secret gist
Convert it to an issue
Merge it into an existing pull request

options.text: is:pr is:open label:test "fix"
is:issue in:comments label:test "fix"
is:issue is:open label:test "fix"
type:issue label:test is:open body:"fix"

text: Which of the following are valid states for a pull request on GitHub? (Choose four.)

options.text: Open
Draft
Merged
Closed
Pending
Abandoned

text: Which statement best describes a major difference between new GitHub Projects and GitHub Projects Classic?

options.text: The new GitHub Projects provide a flexible spreadsheet-like interface, custom fields, and two-way issue synchronization that were not available in Projects Classic.
GitHub Projects Classic has a built-in AI that automatically closes pull requests, while the new GitHub Projects do not.
GitHub Projects Classic supports code scanning and secret scanning, while the new GitHub Projects do not.
The new GitHub Projects only allow you to manage open issues without supporting pull requests.

text: Which of these can you customize in a Codespaces .devcontainer/devcontainer.json configuration file? (Choose three.)

options.text: Operating system or base image
Shell configuration
GitHub Actions billing usage
Codespace display name
Repository branch protection rules
Organization-level policies

text: Which roles in an organization can view and manage security alerts for private repositories?

options.text: Outside collaborators
Repository maintainers
Organization owners and Security managers
Billing managers

explanation: **More info**: [Roles in an organization](https://docs.github.com/en/organizations/managing-peoples-access-to-your-organization-with-roles/roles-in-an-organization). Outside collaborators have repository-specific permissions only and are not organization members with security privileges.. Maintainers can manage certain repository settings but do not have default access to organization-wide security alerts.. **Correct**. Organization owners and Security managers can view and manage security alerts, including for private repositories.

text: Which of these statements accurately describes a difference between personal accounts and organization accounts on GitHub?

options.text: An organization account can have multiple owners and members, whereas a personal account belongs to a single user only.
A personal account allows unlimited private repositories, but an organization account only allows public repositories.
A personal account can only be accessed via SSH keys, while an organization account can only be accessed via passwords.
An organization account can only be created if you have a GitHub Enterprise plan.

explanation: **More info**: [Types of GitHub accounts](https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/learning-about-github/types-of-github-accounts). **Correct**. Organizations allow for collaborative management by multiple people, while a personal account is tied to an individual.. Organizations are available on Free, Team, or Enterprise plans.

text: Which statement best describes the difference between cloning a repository and forking a repository?

options.text: When you clone a repository, changes you push go directly to the original repository. Forking requires a separate local copy.
Forking creates a copy under your GitHub account, while cloning creates a local copy on your computer without linking ownership to your account.
Cloning always transfers repository ownership, while forking does not.
Only private repositories can be forked, whereas only public repositories can be cloned.

explanation: **More info**: [About forks](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/about-forks). Cloning and forking both result in separate local copies, but pushing to a clone requires the correct permission on the original repo.. **Correct**. A fork is a GitHub-level copy that appears in your account, whereas a clone is a local-only copy.

text: Which of these statements about pinned items on your GitHub profile is true?

options.text: You can pin up to 10 repositories on your profile.
You can pin up to six repositories or gists on your profile for quick access.
You can only pin public repositories, not private ones.
Pinning an item deletes it from your repository list.

explanation: **More info**: [Pinning items to your profile](https://docs.github.com/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-managing-your-github-profile/customizing-your-profile/pinning-items-to-your-profile). **Correct**. GitHub supports pinning up to six items (repositories or gists).

text: Which advanced search operator combination would you use to find public repositories with more than 100 stars that mention 'docker' in their name?

options.text: `in:name docker stars:
docker in:description stars:<100 is:public
is:public name:docker stars:100
`topic:docker stars:

explanation: **More info**: [Searching repositories](https://docs.github.com/en/search-github/searching-on-github/searching-for-repositories). **Correct**. This will find all public repositories that have 'docker' in their name and more than 100 stars.. This is missing the range operator (`>`) for stars, and `name:docker` is not a valid syntax.. This searches within topics or readmes, not the repository name.

text: Which of the following best describes GitHub secret scanning?

options.text: A feature that scans issues for unverified credentials and deletes them automatically.
A feature that encrypts your repository secrets before pushing them to GitHub.
A feature that runs third-party password managers on your code to store secrets securely.
A feature that searches repositories for known secret formats to prevent accidental exposure of sensitive data.

explanation: **More info**: [About secret scanning](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/secret-scanning/about-secret-scanning). Secret scanning doesn't automatically delete anything; it detects potentially leaked secrets.. GitHub Actions Encrypted Secrets handle encryption, but that’s different from secret scanning.. **Correct**. Secret scanning detects tokens, keys, and other credentials to help avoid leaks.

text: Which of these statements about GitHub Pages is correct?

options.text: GitHub Pages allows you to host a private website for free, accessible only by organization members.
GitHub Pages enables you to host static sites from a GitHub repository.
GitHub Pages automatically converts Java files into dynamic web apps.
GitHub Pages can only be used by organization accounts.

explanation: **More info**: [About GitHub Pages](https://docs.github.com/en/pages/getting-started-with-github-pages/about-github-pages). GitHub Pages sites are always publicly accessible, unless you use a project site with enterprise firewall rules on GitHub Enterprise Server.. **Correct**. GitHub Pages is specifically for static site hosting from your repo.. Both personal and organization accounts can use Pages.
